stem: A client with a T4 spinal cord injury reports a severe, throbbing headache. BP is 198/104. The nurse notes flushing above the level of injury and cool skin below. Complete the bowtie to manage this crisis.

actions.text: Place the client in a high-Fowler's position
Administer IV Beta-blockers as first-line treatment
Check for bladder distension or catheter kinking

rationale.correct: High-Fowler's (sitting up) uses gravity to help lower intracranial BP. Finding and removing the trigger (Bladder/Bowel) is definitive. BP and bladder/bowel status are the primary monitoring items.
rationale.incorrect: Laying flat will worsen the hypertension. Vasodilators (not beta blockers) are used if the trigger removal doesn't lower BP quickly enough.
clinicalPearls: Always check the bladder first, then the bowel (impaction), then the skin (restrictive clothing).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Sitting the client up is the FIRST action; fixing the bladder is the next/definitive action.
